column1: ap ~ 02:55|"about five to three"|"It was many
column2: many years since I had tackled this kind of job
column3: but the old skill came back as good as ever. Having got the bag so nicely poised that a touch on the door would do all that was necessary
column4: I skipped down from my chair
column6: and went into the street. Sippy had not shown up yet
column7: which was all to the good
column8: but I knew he usually trickled in at about five to three. I hung about in the street
column9: and presently round the corner came the bloke Waterbury. He went in at the front door
column10: and I started off for a short stroll. It was no part of my policy to be in the offing when things began to happen."|"Very Good

column1: ap ~ 03:15|"about three-fifteen"|"It seemed to me that
column3: the scales should have fallen from old Sippy’s eyes by about three-fifteen
column4: Greenwich mean time; so

column6: I retraced my steps and pushed up the stairs. I went in at the door marked Private
column7: fully expecting to see old Sippy
column8: and conceive of my astonishment and chagrin when I found on entering only the bloke Waterbury. He was seated at Sippy’s desk
column10: as if the place belonged to him."|"Very Good

column3: as I had foreseen
column4: a good deal of revelry and what not. First
column5: the village choir surged round and sang carols outside the front door

column1: 03:00|"three o’clock in the morning"|"‘I did. I was aware that you and my nephew were on terms of intimacy

column1: ap 01:30|one-thirty|"‘At one-thirty. Right. Good. Fine. Thanks. I knew I could rely on you.’"|"Very Good
ap 01:25|one-twenty-five|"I can’t say I exactly saw eye to eye with young Tuppy in his admiration for the Bellinger female. Delivered on the mat at one-twenty-five
column2: she proved to be an upstanding light-heavyweight of some thirty summers
column3: with a commanding eye and a square chin which I
column4: personally
column5: would have steered clear of. She seemed to me a good deal like what Cleopatra would have been after going in too freely for the starches and cereals. I don’t know why it is
column6: but women who have anything to do with Opera
column7: even if they’re only studying for it
column8: always appear to run to surplus poundage."|"Very Good

column2: the Bellinger left to go to a singing lesson. Tuppy trotted after her to the door
column3: bleating and frisking a goodish bit
column4: and then came back and looked at me in a goofy sort of way."|"Very Good

column1: ap ~ 10:30|"about half-past ten"|"It must have been about half-past ten
column2: and I was in the old sitting-room sombrely sucking down a more or less final restorative
column3: when the front-door bell rang
column4: and there on the mat was young Tuppy. He looked like a man who has passed through some great experience and stood face to face with his soul. He had the beginnings of a black eye."|"Very Good

column1: ap 06:00|six|"‘I said “Ha!” Jeeves. And I meant “Ha!” I was registering relief. My Aunt Agatha returns this evening. She will be at her town residence between the hours of six and seven
column2: and she expects to find McIntosh waiting for her on the mat.’"|"Very Good

column1: ap 05:30|five-thirty|"‘Wonderful. Everything went off splendidly. The lunch was just right. The child stuffed himself to the eyebrows and got more and more amiable

column3: and he sat there absorbing it in a sort of gorged way
column4: and at the end old Blumenfeld said “Well

column1: ap 10:15|ten-fifteen|"The more I thought it over
column2: the better that idea of sending those roses looked. Lucius Pim was not a man I was fond of – in fact
column3: if I had had to choose between him and a cockroach as a companion for a walking-tour
column4: the cockroach would have had it by a short head – but there was no doubt that he had outlined the right policy. His advice was good
column5: and I decided to follow it. Rising next morning at ten-fifteen
column6: I swallowed a strengthening breakfast and legged it off to that flower-shop in Piccadilly. I couldn’t leave the thing to Jeeves. It was essentially a mission that demanded the personal touch. I laid out a couple of quid on a sizeable bouquet
column7: sent it with my card to Hill Street
column8: and then looked in at the Drones for a brief refresher. It is a thing I don’t often do in the morning
column9: but this threatened to be rather a special morning."|"Very Good

column1: ~ 12:00|"about noon"|"It was about noon when I got back to the flat. I went into the sitting-room and tried to adjust the mind to the coming interview. It had to be faced
column3: but it wasn’t any good my telling myself that it was going to be one of those jolly scenes the memory of which cheer you up as you sit toasting your toes at the fire in your old age. I stood or fell by the roses. If they sweetened the Slingsby
column4: all would be well. If they failed to sweeten her
column5: Bertram was undoubtedly for it."|"Very Good

column1: ap 02:30|two-thirty|"‘I will tell you. If the telegram arrived earlier
column2: he would get it before the game. By two-thirty
column3: however
column4: he will have started for the ground. I shall hand it to him the moment there is a lull in the battle. By that time he will have begun to get some idea of what a football match between Upper Bleaching and Hockley-cum-Meston is like

column1: ap 02:30|Two-thirty|"You can always rely on Jeeves. Two-thirty I had said

column4: and half a minute later the whistle blew and the war was on."|"Very Good
